body.p:
I should judge from your letter that when you wrote you had not
received the ? liner I had sent you by Mrs. Lyons, who nevertheless
had promised to call on you on her journey to her new home. But
I have little doubt that she fulfilled her promise by calling before she
left, and that she likewise told aunt R all the particulars about
the wedding. I am well aware that ladies like to hear such
matters; but I am but little acquainted with them to give full
particulars. The wedding however was a tolerably merry one,
and plenty to eat and to drink was set before all the com-
pany. As usual some affronts were given; since some persons
thought themselves entitled to an invitation which was not extended
to them. Among the rest a cousin of the bride, who expected to be unter-
ferer, and not being asked she and and husband did not come
at all. However this you know is not uncommon; I myself staid till
near one o'clock; as they did not sit down to supper till a quarter before
twelve, and I was expected to stay to say prayers. It was rather
a later hour for me than I liked to remain out of bed; but as there was
no help for it I had to submit.

Old Mr Wolff has been at our house for some weeks.
He had a cataract on one eye, and could not see well out of
the other. He had accordingly an operation before? to remove
the cataract from the one eye, already Sunday two weeks ago;
and as yet he has not been down stairs. As my room is I think
the most convenient in the house I gave it up to him; though I
do not hold him in very high estimation, since he is for a European
as little of a Jew as ever I saw in my life. However he too has
not escaped without his share of trouble. I hope that in a week or two
he may be able to travel southwards as he lives in Mobile, Alabama; a person sick in a house makes a great difference in all arrange
ments.

As I am writing a message is brought that Rachel Pyke (Peixotto) was
last night confined; but the child is dead. I do not admire that couple
much. I have recommended him to several persons to give him goods
on commission; but he invariably has failed of paying over what he
sold, and so he will get but little more from Jews. He has cost me
besides somewhat like twenty Dollars in money, and more indirectly,
and from me therefore he has nothing to expect. Upon the whole there
is little satisfaction in doing anything for the poor of this community. They
generally eat up what they get; and but small thanks do even fall to
my share at least; I know not how it may be with other people. It
would not matter much if I were rich; but having to work for every cent
I get, it is rather hard that so many make constant claim to the
little I have, and do it in such a manner that a refusal is out of my
power. I have determined at times not to be liberal; but I see no way
whatever to avoid giving more than I should do for my means. Still
as I am a single man and having no one whom I need work for, it makes
but small odds at last, as I hope with God's Helping to be always able to earn
my living; and if I have this respectably I have no right to ask for more.

My intention was to go to New York last Sunday. But Mr. S. Pesoa
was on Thursday & Friday so ill, that the Doctor had no hopes of his
living to the utmost more than 72 hours. But last evening I went
to see him, and he appeared to me not to be quite so sick as that he
might not recover. Doctor Jackson happened to come in as I was
going away, and I waited till he was going again, when he asked
to ride down in his carriage, and took me to 8th & Chestnut Streets
(believe in 8th below Walnut); he then told me that there is but small
probability of his recovery, yet there is no symptom which would make
his disease necessarily fatal. So I trust, that the poor young man
may get up again, especially as he has four to five children & a helpless wife
depending for support upon his daily exertions. I thought that the family might
think it unkind in me to leave the city under these circumstances, so I reach?

up my mind to defer my journey, though I thereby will in all probabili
ty lose the fine weather which we now have. Next Sunday
I have יאהר צייט for my father and on Tuesday I believe they will
set a tombstone for Mr Allen, when his year expires; so I shall
not get off next week either. So you see, Uncle, that my little
excursion depend upon so many circumstances, that I can not even
leave within the week if I feel ever so much inclined to travel.

Have any Baltimorean signed the prospectus for the Occident?
I have about 60 already in Philadelphia and vicinity, and expect at
least 20 more; how many there are in New York I shall learn only
when I get there; as the people there are too busy to write.
I myself would never have thought of a paper for the present;
but I have been induced to give the proposal in consequence
of solicitation from various quarters. Whether the very persons who
urged me will do any thing appears very doubtful; but there is ?
consolation if I do not print the paper I shall lose nothing by ?

All your friends desire to be remembered; Amelia Allen in particu
lar told me I must mention her name. It is hardly requisite to
write a page full of names; so I leave you to judge who all
enquire about you. Give my love to Aunt R. Rachel, Mr Judah
Mr. & Mrs Block, the Ettings, and all our mutual friends.
